t: Job 41
“Can*pn you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook or*ld press down his tongue with a cord?
Can*ln you put a rope in his nose or*ld pierce his jaw with a hook?
Will*ln he make many pleas to you? Will*ld he speak to you soft words?
Will*ln he make a covenant with you to*ld take him for your servant forever?
Will*ln you play with him as with a bird, or*ld will you put him on a leash for your girls?
Will*ln traders bargain over him? Will*ld they divide him up among the merchants?
Can*ln you fill his skin with harpoons or*ld his head with fishing spears?
Lay*ln your hands on him; remember*ld the battle— you will not do it again!
Behold,*ln the hope of a man is false; he*ld is laid low even at the sight of him.
No*ln one is so fierce that he dares to stir him up. Who*ld then is he who can stand before me?
Who*ln has first given to me, that I should repay him? Whatever*ld is under the whole heaven is mine.
“I*pn will not keep silence concerning his limbs, or*ld his mighty strength, or his goodly frame.
Who*ln can strip off his outer garment? Who*ld would come near him with a bridle?
Who*ln can open the doors of his face? Around*ld his teeth is terror.
His*ln back is made of rows of shields, shut*ld up closely as with a seal.
One*ln is so near to another that*ld no air can come between them.
They*ln are joined one to another; they*ld clasp each other and cannot be separated.
His*ln sneezings flash forth light, and*ld his eyes are like the eyelids of the dawn.
Out*ln of his mouth go flaming torches; sparks*ld of fire leap forth.
Out*ln of his nostrils comes forth smoke, as*ld from a boiling pot and burning rushes.
His*ln breath kindles coals, and*ld a flame comes forth from his mouth.
In*ln his neck abides strength, and*ld terror dances before him.
The*ln folds of his flesh stick together, firmly*ld cast on him and immovable.
His*ln heart is hard as a stone, hard*ld as the lower millstone.
When*ln he raises himself up, the mighty are afraid; at*ld the crashing they are beside themselves.
Though*ln the sword reaches him, it does not avail, nor*ld the spear, the dart, or the javelin.
He*ln counts iron as straw, and*ld bronze as rotten wood.
The*ln arrow cannot make him flee; for*ld him, sling stones are turned to stubble.
Clubs*ln are counted as stubble; he*ld laughs at the rattle of javelins.
His*ln underparts are like sharp potsherds; he*ld spreads himself like a threshing sledge on the mire.
He*ln makes the deep boil like a pot; he*ld makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
Behind*ln him he leaves a shining wake; one*ld would think the deep to be white-haired.
On*ln earth there is not his like, a*ld creature without fear.
He*ln sees everything that is high; he*ld is king over all the sons of pride.”
